free_text.Learning outcomes: To describe the different aspects in the development of a knee implant by considering :[br/][li] clinical context for orthopedic engineering[br/][li] outcome measurement in orthopedics and evaluation of functional performance[br/][li] biomechanics theory and numerical methods[br/]
free_text.Content: 1. Clinical perspective : knee arthrosis, knee autonomy for implant develppment consideration (Prof B. Jolles-Haeberli)[br/]2. Kinematics measurements (Prof. K. Aminian)[br/]3. Knee biomechanics (Prof. D. Pioletti)[br/]4. Pre-operating planning + Possibility to see a knee surgery or visit the operating rooms (Prof. Brigitte Jolles-Haeberli, Mrs. Els Drubbels)[br/]5. Knee implant numerical studies (Dr A. Terrier)[br/]6. Knee implant : CE mark and industrialization (M. Vincent Leclercq et Prof. Brigitte Jolles-Haeberli)[br/]

free_text.Contenu: [br/]Part 1: Clinical background[br/][br/][][]- Knee ligament pathology[br/][][]- Cartilage pathology[br/][][]- Orthopedic implant[br/][br/]Part 2: General biomechanics in orthopedics[br/][br/][][]- Review of the major human joints, their prosthetic replacement and the related clinical problems.[br/][][]- Continuum mechanics of deformable bodies: conservation laws, constitutive laws and evolution laws.[br/][][]- Numerical methods: geometric reconstruction, finite element method, non-linearity.[br/][][]- Application of the presented methods to a specific problem: stress analysis of bone and soft structures.[br/][br/]Part 3: Constitutive laws[br/][br/][][]- Definition of variables: strain and stress tensors[br/][][]- Definition and exemples of constitutive laws[br/][][]- Description of the identification process for a particular constitutive law[br/][br/]Part 4: Background for soft tissue biomechanics[br/][br/][][]- Tissue, cell, and molecular scales; cell biological responses to mechanical stimulation.[br/][][]- Mechanical properties; poroelastic mechanics.[br/][][]- Transport properties; transport kinetics; diffusion-convection.[br/][][]- Electrokinetic phenomena; the electrical double layer; molecular modelling.[br/][][]- Biomechanics of cartilage injury and tissue engineering; physical diagnosis of cartilage degradation.
free_text.Objectifs d'apprentissage: 1. to describe the clinical context for orthopedic engineering[br/][br/]2. to introduce the biomechanics theory and the numerical methods developed in orthopedics research[br/][br/]3. to learn in the context of biomechanics, how to identify experimental results to a theoretical description[br/][br/]4. to understand relationships between molecular structure and macroscopic function of soft tissues
